SafetyInspectionBy: Ammonia detection system tested and calibrated

Emergency Response Program
Central Storage Warehouse employees have not been trained in emergency response and will not respond to emergency ammonia releases. An Emergency Action Plan (EAP) has been developed that includes coordination with local response agencies, procedures for employees to follow in the event of an accidental release of ammonia and a list of emergency phone numbers. Employees have been trained on how to use the plan and drills carried out annually.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Through the accidental release prevention program, Central Storage Warehouse, regularly evaluates the need for any changes to improve safety. Projects that affect the process's safety that are currently being considered are: Compressor Room ammonia detection update to IIAR 2-2021 standards and emergency ventilation being updated to IIAR 2-2021 standards.

Information: Information pertaining to the hazards of ammonia, the technology of the process and the equipment in the process. 
	Process Hazard Analysis (PHA): A PHA review of the ammonia refrigeration process was conducted to identify hazards and safeguards pertaining to the ammonia refrigeration system.
	Operating procedures were developed and implemented for the safe operation of the refrigeration system.
	Safe work practices were developed and implemented for lockout/tagout, confined space and opening equipment and piping. 
	A Mechanical Integrity program is being implemented to maintain the on-going integrity and safety of the refrigeration system, including application of the following industry codes and standards: 
	ASME Boiler & Pressure Valve Codes
	ANSI B31.3 Piping Code
	ANSI/IIAR 2-2008 American National Standard for Equipment, Design, and Installation of Closed-Circuit Ammonia Mechanical Refrigerating Systems
	ANSI/IIAR 2-20014 American National Standard for Equipment, Design, and Installation of Closed-Circuit Ammonia Mechanical Refrigerating Systems
	ANSI/IIAR 2-2021 American National Standard for Equipment, Design, and Installation of Closed-Circuit Ammonia Mechanical Refrigerating Systems
	ANSI/ASHRAE Standard 15
	NFPA guidelines for fire protection equipment
	A Management of Change (MOC) program and procedures were developed to address all proposed changes to the refrigeration system.
	Pre-startup Safety Review (PSSR) procedures were developed.
	A detailed compliance audit checklist is used to evaluate compliance with the Process Safety Management and Risk Management programs every three years.
	Developed incident investigation procedures to analyze and review accidents or near-misses involving the refrigeration system.
	Establish a Hot Work Permit system.
	Developed and implemented a program to evaluate contractors and contractor employees.

RMP EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances
Central Storage Warehouse, located at 7800 95th St. Pleasant Prairie, WI, is a frozen foods storage facility with modern capabilities.
At this facility, anhydrous ammonia (Cas #7664-41-7) is used as a refrigerant to cool or freeze product for storage and shipment. The refrigeration system is a closed-loop, mechanical refrigeration system. Liquid ammonia is supplied by pump or pressure differential to the freezers, docks, and cooler area evaporators for cooling and freezing purposes. Ammonia vapor and liquid from the evaporators returns to the Recirculator and Intercooler vessels in the engine room. The normal high-side operating pressure ranges from 120 to 185 psig. The maximum allowable working pressure is 250 psig. The quantity of ammonia on site, is 12,000 lbs.
As part of the PSM program, Central Storage and Warehouse has completed a Process Hazard Analysis, developed written operating procedures, trained employees on awareness and system operation, established procedures to conduct management of change procedures and pre-startup safety reviews, and developed a mechanical integrity program for ammonia refrigeration equipment. In addition to the daily monitoring of the refrigeration process, Central Storage and Warehouse implements an ongoing preventive maintenance program to ensure the refrigeration equipment and safety systems are maintained in good operating condition.
General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
A PSM program, which meets the requirements of the RMP general accidental release prevention program, is being implemented by Central Storage Warehouse to address the anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system at the Pleasant Prairie, WI facility. The PSM program developed and implemented at Central Storage Warehouse includes the following steps:
	Written plans for implementing employee participation in PSM.
	Process Safety
